Impact of malaria morbidity of a programme supplying insecticide treated nets in children aged under 2 years in Tanzania: Community cross sectional study

Abdulla, S. et al. (2001)
British Medical Journal, 322: 270-273
Location Tanzania
Population Children under age 2
Intervention Description Social marketing of ITNs and insecticide
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Net ownership of treated nets increased 10% to 61% Health: Prevalence of parasitemia and haemoglobin levels; prevalence of anemia decreased from 49% to 26%; Treated nets had a protective efficacy of 62% on prevalence of parasitaemia and of 63% on anaemia.
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 1: Methods mix

Spatial effects of the social marketing of insecticide-treated nets on malaria morbidity

Abdulla, S. et al. (2005)
Tropical Medicine and International Health, 10 (1): 11–18.
Location Tanzania
Population Households
Intervention Description Social marketing of ITNs
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Coverage, distribution pattern and resultant spatial effects Behaviors: Percent of children using a treated net Health: Prevalence of parasitaemia, mild anaemia (Hb <11 g/dl) and moderate/severe anaemia (Hb <8 g/dl) in children under five; children living in areas of moderately high ITN coverage were about half as likely to have moderate/severe anaemia
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 0

The impact of a hybrid social marketing intervention on inequities in access, ownership and use of insecticide-treated nets

Agha, S.; Van Rossem, R.; Stallworthy, G.; and Kusanthan, T. (2007)
Malaria Journal, 6(13)
Location Eastern Province, Zambia
Population Household survey; Men and women ages 15-49
Intervention Description ITN subsidy and social marketing intervention to increase knowledge, access, and use of ITNs as part of the Roll Back Malaria Campain. Distribution was through public health facilities.
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Knowledge of malaria and ITNs, access to ITNs, beliefs about malaria protection, ownership (number of ITNs in the household) Behaviors: Usage of ITNs (respondent usually sleeps under a net)
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 7: Customer orientation, Behavior, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

Improvements in access to malaria treatment in Tanzania following community, retail sector and health facility interventions -- a user perspective

Alba, S. et al. (2010)
Malaria Journal, 9(163)
Location Ifakara, Tanzania
Population Treatment-seeking surveys of people who had suffered a fever case in the previous 14 days
Intervention Description Social Marketing for improved treatment seeking
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Improvements in understanding causes of malaria (from 62% to 84%); higher treatment coverage with anti-malarials (86% to 96%) Behavior: Increases in health facility attendance as first treatment option for patients older than five years (27% to 52%); more timely use of anti-malarials (80% to 93-97% treatments taken within 24 hrs).
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Segmentation, Methods mix

Lessons learned from bednet distribution in Central Mozambique

Brentlinger, P.E. (2007)
Health Policy Plan, 22(2):103-10
Location Sofala and Manica, Central Mozambique
Population Household survey
Intervention Description Commericial shopkeeepers and community leaders were trained to promote/sell ITNs in 19 sites between 2000-2004
Outcomes Behavioral factor: ITN ownership;
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2:Exchange, Methods mix

Effect of expanded insecticide-treated bednet coverage on child survival in rural Kenya: a longitudinal study

Fegan, G. W.; Noor, A. M.; Akhwale, W. S.; Cousens, S.; and Snow, R. W. (2007)
Lancet, 370(9592): 1035–1039
Location Kenya
Population Children aged 1–59 months
Intervention Description Combined approach of social marketing and free distribution of ITNs
Outcomes Behavior: Increase in ITN use by children aged less than 5 years from 7% in 2004, to 23·5% in 2005, to 67% in 2006 Health: ITN use was associated with a 44% reduction in mortality
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 0

Sustained high coverage of insecticide-treated bednets through combined Catch-up and Keep-up strategies

Grabowsky, M.; Nobiya, T.; and Selanikio, J.
Tropical Medicine and International Health, 12 (7): 815–822
Location Ghana
Population Households with at least one child less than 5 years of age
Intervention Description Mass, free distribution (Catch-up) of insecticide-treated bednets (ITNs) during measles vaccination campaigns, followed by antenatal clinic-based social marketing for routine Keep-up on ITN coverage and use
Outcomes Behavioral factors: 95.7% of children slept in a household that had a net, 86.1% slept in a household that had a campaign net Behavior: 59.6% of children slept under an ITN
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Behavior, Exchange, Segmentation, Method mix

Household ownership and use of insecticide treated nets among target groups after implementation of a national voucher programme in the United Republic of Tanzania: plausibility study using three annual cross sectional household surveys

Hanson, K et al. (2009)
British Medical Journal, 339
Location Tanzania
Population Household survey
Intervention Description Social marketing combined with the National Voucher Scheme targeting mothers of young children at antenatal clinics
Outcomes Behavioral factors: ITN ownership increased from 18% to 36% Behavior: Among infants under 1 year of age, use of an ITN increased from 16% to 34%
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Cost-effectiveness of social marketing of insecticide-treated nets for malaria control in the United Republic of Tanzania

Hanson, K. et al. (2003)
Bulletin of the World Health Organization, 81 (4)
Location Kilombero and Ulanga districts, Tanzania
Population Case-control study on child survival and demographic surveillance system
Intervention Description ITN and insecticide social marketing
Outcomes Behavior: ITN coverage, measured as the proportion of children that slept under a treated net the previous night, was 14% in Ulanga and 23% in Kilombero in July and August 1999. Health: Given the estimate of 27% for protective efficacy from the case–control study, this indicates 96 deaths averted or 2588 DALYs averted in 1999.
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Customer Orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Method mix

Insecticide-treated bednet use, anaemia, and malaria parasitaemia in Blantyre District, Malawi

Holtz, T.H. et al. (2002)
Tropical Medicine and International Health, 7 (3): 220–230
Location Blantyre District, Malawi
Population Households with at least one child less than 5 years of age
Intervention Description Social marketing of ITNs (PSI)
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Bednet ownership was low (20.5% of households) Behaviors:Only 3.3% of rural children under 5 had slept under a net the previous night, compared with 24.0% of urban children Health: rural children under 5 in households without nets experienced a statistically significant higher prevalence of malaria parasitaemia [RR 4.9] than children in households with at least one bednet
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer Orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Access to artemisinin-based anti-malarial treatment and its related factors in rural Tanzania

Khatib, R.A. et al. (2013)
Malaria Journal, 12(155)
Location Kilombero-Ulanga and Rufiji Districts in Tanzania
Population Rolling household surveys from 2009-2011
Intervention Description Social marketing of ACTs and private and accredited drug dispensing outlets (ADDOs) were implemented in certain districts
Outcomes Behavioral factors: No significance difference in 24 hour access to ACT outlets for households experiencing fever between a district with ADDOs plus social marketing and one without.
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 0

The economics of social marketing:the case of mosquito nets in Tanzania

Kikumbih, N.; Hanson, K.; Mills, A.; Mponda, H.; and Schellenberg, J. A. (2005)
Social Science & Medicine 60: 369–381
Location Kilombero and Kilosa, Uganda
Population Household survey; Men and women
Intervention Description Kilombero and Ulanga insecticide-treated net (KINET) project used social marketing to promote Zuia Mbu nets and insecticide treatment kits
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Knowledge about ITNS and insecticide treatment, coverage (proportion of households with at least one net)
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Customer orientation, Behavior, Segmentation, Methods mix

Reduction of childhood malaria by social marketing of insecticide-treated nets: a case-control study of effectiveness in Malawi

Mathanga, D.P.; Campbell, C.H.; Taylor, T.E.; Barlow, R.; and Wilson, M.L. (2005)
The American journal of tropical medicine and hygiene, 73 (3): 622-625
Location Blantyre, Malawi
Population Case-control study of children under 5 with history of fever within last 48 hours
Intervention Description ITN social marketing (PSI)
Outcomes Behavioral factors: ITN coverage Health: Individual effectiveness of ITN use was 40% (95% confidence interval [CI] 10–60%) when cases were compared with clinic controls and 50% (95% CI 0–60%) in comparison with community controls; 1,480 malaria cases averted by the intervention in a population of 15,000 children
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Segmentation, Methods mix

Socially marketed insecticide-treated nets effectively reduce Plasmodium infection and anaemia among children in urban Malawi

Mathanga, D.P.; Campbell, C.H.; Taylor, T.E.; Barlow, R.; and Wilson, M.L. (2006)
Tropical Medicine and International Health, 11 (9): 1367-1374
Location Ndirande, Blantyre, Malawi
Population Children age 6-59 months
Intervention Description ITN social marketing (PSI)
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Knowledge of ITNs Behavior: 42% of children reported ITN use the previous night Health: 17% (295/1721) of children had a positive P. falciparum smear at enrolment. Use of ITNs was associated with 52% protective efficacy against Plasmodium parasitemia. More than two-thirds of children were anaemic, yet the mean haemoglobin concentration was significantly higher in children using ITNs than in those not using nets.
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Segmentation, Methods mix

Comparison of coverage with insecticide-treated nets in a Tanzanian town and villages where nets and insecticide are either marketed or provided free of charge

Maxwell, C.A.; Rwegoshora, R.T.; Magesa, S.M.; and Curtis, C.F. (2006)
Malaria Journal, 5(44)
Location North-east Tanzania
Population Household survey; Men and women
Intervention Description Social marketing of ITNs and insecticide
Outcomes Behavioral factors: % of households that purchased a net, % of households with intact treated nexts Behavior: % of households reporting usage in urban and rural areas that had social marketing were compared to areas with free distribution
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 2
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 0

Health Microinsurance, Social Marketing, and Disease Prevention: Perspectives from the Field

McCord, J. and Rivers, K. (2007)
Intl Journal of Public Administration, 30: 791–812
Location South-western (Kisiizi and Ishaka) Uganda
Population Microinsurance organization clients over the age of 18
Intervention Description Comparison of health microinsurance organization clients who only had basic health education verus those exposed to social marketing of SmartNet ITN
Outcomes Behavioral factors: knowledge, perceptions, barriers, sources of information; perceptions of ITNs were more positive and rates of ownership were higher among those exposed to social marketing
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 1
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Behavior, Customer Orientation, Theory, Method Mix

Distribution Systems of Insecticide-Treated Bed Nets for Malaria Control in Rural Burkina Faso: Cluster- Randomized Controlled Trial

Muller, O. et al. (2008)
PLoS ONE 3(9): e3182
Location Burkina Faso
Population Households
Intervention Description Subsidized ITN distribution through social marketing with or without free ITN distribution (free distribution took place through antenatal clinics)
Outcomes Behavioral factors: ITN ownership increased in SM with free distribution areas more than in SM only areas from baseline to follow-up Behaviors: Increases in Bednet use in previous night was similarly higher in both groups from baseline to follow-up; use among pregnant women and children under five increased in SM with free distribution from 44% to 50% and in SM only from 37% to 44%.
Design Experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 6
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Segmentation, Methods Mix

Mosquito nets and the poor: can social marketing redress inequities in access?

Nathan, R. et al. (2004)
Tropical Medicine and International Health, 9 (10):1121–1126
Location Rural Tanzania
Population Households
Intervention Description Social marketing of treated nets over three year period
Outcomes Behavioral factors: Ownership increased 37% to 73%; among poorest households ownership of at least one net increased 20% to 54%
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 5: Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

Increasing coverage and decreasing inequity in insecticide-treated bed net use among rural Kenyan children

Noor, A.M.; Amin, A.A.; Akhwale, W.S.; and Snow, R.W. (2007)
PLoS medicine, 4(8)
Location Bondo, Greater Kisii, Kwale, and Makueni Districts, Kenya
Population Children age 0-4 years
Intervention Description At baseline only commercial social marketing (PSI) was in place. Heavily subsidized MCH clinic distribution (PSI) and free distribution were implemented during the course of the study
Outcomes Behavior: At baseline only 7% of children slept under a net treated with insecticide within 6 months the night before the survey. At 12 months, this increased to 23% and at 24 months this increased to 67% with the majority of ITNs obtained via free distribution and heavily subsidized distribution at MCH clinics
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix

The use of Insecticide-Treated bed Net in a semi-urban community in south-south, Nigeria

Ordinioha, B. (2007)
Nigerian Journal of Medicine, 16(3): 223-226
Location South-south Nigeria
Population Households
Intervention Description Social marketing of ITNs
Outcomes Behaviors: Of 311 ITNs sold through the project, 18.28% were properly deployed during monitoring visit; 79.59% of properly deployed nets were occupied by children under five
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Segmentation, Method mix

DEET mosquito repellent sold through social marketing provides personal protection against malaria in an area of all-night mosquito biting and partial coverage of insecticide-treated nets: a case-control study of effectiveness

Rowland, M.; Freeman, T.; Downey, G.; Hadi, A.; and Saeed, M. (2004)
Tropical medicine & international health, 9(3): 343-350
Location Behsud district, Nangahar province, eastern Afghanistan
Population Case-control study of outpatients with febrile illness
Intervention Description Social marketing of a repellent soap containing DEET
Outcomes Behavior: Mosbar was purchased by 43% of households. among the control group. There was a strong association between Mosbar use and ITN use, as 81% of Mosbar users also possessed ITN. Health: The use of Mosbar was associated with a 45% reduction in the odds of malaria after adjusting for ITN and other unmatched factors
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Insight, Methods mix

Prevention of malaria in Afghanistan through social marketing of insecticide-treated nets: evaluation of coverage and effectiveness by cross-sectional surveys and passive surveillance

Rowland, M. et al. (2002)
Tropical medicine & international health, 7(10): 813-822
Location Afghanistan
Population Cross-sectional surveys of housholds and passive surveillance from clinics using case-control design
Intervention Description ITN and insecticide social marketing
Outcomes Behavior: Nets were purchased by 59% of families. Health: Cross-sectional surveys demonstrated a 59% reduction in the risk of Plasmodium falciparum infection among ITN users compared with non-users and the passive surveillance method showed a 69% reduction in the risk of symptomatic P. falciparum malaria among ITN users; reductions in risk of P. vivax infection was also seen, but only statistically significant under passive surveillance
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 2: Exchange, Methods mix

KINET: a social marketing programme of treated nets and net treatment for malaria control in Tanzania, with evaluation of child health and long-term survival

Schellenberg, J. R. et al. (1999)
Trans R Soc Trop Med Hyg, 93(3):225-31
Location Kilombero and Ulanga Districts in South-western Tanzania
Population Cross-sectional survey among households
Intervention Description ITN and insecticide social marketing
Outcomes Behavioral factor: 24% of households had at least one treated net Behavior: 18 months after launching, 46% of 312 families with children aged under 5 years reported that their children were sleeping under treated nets
Design Observational
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Effect of large-scale social marketing of insecticide-treated nets on child survival in rural Tanzania

Schellenberg, J. R. et al. (2001)
Lancet, 357(9264): 1241-7
Location Kilombero and Ulanga Districts in South-western Tanzania
Population Case-control study among children age 1 month to 4 years and a demographic surveillance system survey of households
Intervention Description ITN social marketing
Outcomes Behavioral factor: Insecticide-treated net coverage of infants in the study area rose from less than 10% at baseline to more than 50% 3 years later. Health: Insecticide-treated nets were associated with a 27% increase in survival in children aged 1 month to 4 years.
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 4
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

The effect of delivery mechanisms on the uptake of bed net re-impregnation in Kilifi District, Kenya

Snow, R.W. et al. (2007)
Health Policy and Planning, 14(1): 18-25
Location Kilifi District, Kenya
Population Households
Intervention Description Retreatment of ITNS was initially offered for free house-to-house, then free at sentinel sites, and then through social marketing and sales
Outcomes Behavior: Net re-impregnation coverage decreased from 97% during free house-to-house delivery to 61-67% when free re-treatment moved to sentinel sites to 7% after the social marketing model was implemented
Design Experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 3: Behavior, Exchange, Methods mix

Use and misuse of a discount voucher scheme as a subsidy for insecticide-treated nets for malaria control in southern Tanzania

Tami, A. et al. (2006)
Health Policy Plan, 21(1):1-9
Location Kilombero and Ulanga districts, southern Tanzania
Population Previously pregnant women, or primary caregivers of children under 5 years of age, whose names were written on a sampled voucher.
Intervention Description A social marketing programme of ITNs and net treatment, including a voucher scheme for targeting subsidies of ITNs for children under 5 years and pregnant women through mother-and-child (MCH) clinics
Outcomes Behavior: 92% of women interviewed slept under a net during pregnancy and of those, 26.5% had used the ITN bought with the voucher; 65% of the women given a voucher because they were pregnant used the ITN acquired with that voucher during pregnancy; Of 93 households with children under 5 years, 77 (83%) reported that all under-fives (103) had slept under a net in the previous night
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 3
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 4: Behavior, Exchange, Segmentation, Methods mix

Socially-marketed rapid diagnostic tests and ACT in the private sector: ten years of experience in Cambodia

Yeung, S.; Patouillard, E.; Allen, H.; and Socheat, D. (2011)
Malaria Journal, 10(243)
Location Cambodia
Population Providers and households
Intervention Description Social marketing of RDTs and ACT
Outcomes Behavioral Factors: Providers knowledge of RDTS and ACT, product availablity, sales/selling price; Consumer awareness of RDTS and ACT Behavior: Providers selling practices and Consumer buying practices of ACTs; Providers use of RDTS
Design Observational
Sampling Method Purposive
Strength of Evidence Score 2
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 7: Behavior, Customer Orientation, Insight, Exchange, Competition, Segmentation, Methods Mix

Access to artemisinin combination therapy for malaria in remote areas of Cambodia

Yeung, S.; Van Damme, W.; Socheat, D.; White, N. J.; and Mills, A. (2008)
Malaria Journal, 7 (96)
Location Cambodia
Population Individuals with a history of fever in the last three weeks in areas with village malaria workers (VMWs), outreach clinics, and in areas with no intervention
Intervention Description Social marketing of blister-packaged artesunate and mefloquine (Malarine ®) and RDTs through VMWs and outreach
Outcomes Behavior: Only 17% of individuals in non-intervention areas reported having had a biological diagnosis for their most recent episode of illness. This was significantly higher in the areas with VMWs (63%) and outreach (35%); VMWs and outreach workers reported always using RDTs. In contrast, only 15% of tests at private health facilities and 69% public health facilities were by RDT; VMW scheme and outreach significantly increased the likelihood of being seen by a trained provider (Adjusted Odds Ratios (AOR) of 148 and 4 respectively) and of receiving A+M (AORs of 2.7 and 7.7 respectively).
Design Quasi-experimental
Sampling Method Probability
Strength of Evidence Score 5
Social Marketing Benchmark Criteria 6: Behavior, Customer orientation, Insight, Competition, Segmentation, Methods mix
